docs.lead_paragraph: The used batteries Americans turn in for recycling are increasingly processed in Mexico, their lead often extracted by crude methods that are illegal in the United States.

headline.seo: Recycled Battery Lead Puts Mexicans in Danger
headline.main: Lead From Old U.S. Batteries Sent to Mexico Raises Risks
headline.print_headline: Used Batteries From U.S. Expose Mexicans to Risk

docs.abstract: Used batteries Americans turn in for recycling are increasingly processed in Mexico, their lead often extracted by crude methods that are illegal in the United States, exposing workers and residents there to dangerous levels of a toxic metal; rising flow of batteries is result of strict Environmental Protection Agency standards on lead pollution, which make domestic recycling more difficult but do not prohibit companies from exporting the work to countries where standards are low.
docs.snippet: The used batteries Americans turn in for recycling are increasingly processed in Mexico, their lead often extracted by crude methods that are illegal in the United States.

byline.contributor: Andrew W. Lehren contributed reporting from New York, and Karla Zabludovsky from Mexico City. David Agren contributed research from Guadalajara, Mexico.
